当中国东北的锦州银行在今年年初表现出陷入困境的迹象时，官方媒体暗示，一位名叫李河君的亿万富翁可能是其问题的幕后黑手。李先生是一位太阳能电池板大亨，曾是中国首富。众所周知，他的公司与该银行有着密切的联系。就在他被捕的消息传出后不久，锦州银行暂停了股票交易，并告诉投资者将重组业务。

奇怪的是，该银行的财务状况看起来状况良好。 2022 年上半年，也就是可获得详细信息的最后一个时期，其整体坏账水平较低。尽管有一个令人担忧的数字——超过 50% 的个人商业贷款已成为不良贷款，但此类贷款仅占其贷款总额的 1%。占银行贷款总额约一半的小微企业贷款表现正常，只有 3% 出现不良贷款。

但这是故事的全部吗？资深银行业分析师杰森·贝德福德表示，从理论上讲，个人企业贷款与小微企业贷款之间没有任何有意义的区别。这两种类型的使用方式相似，并且应提供相似的风险。但在实践中，存在一个关键的区别：小微企业贷款仍然受到新冠病毒时代暂停贷款的保护，这使得银行可以避免确认坏账。因此，锦州的贷款账簿中可能有很大一部分是未确认的坏账。自今年早些时候以来，该银行几乎没有透露任何有关其状况的信息。

如果此类隐性坏账潜伏在锦州银行，那么它们也可能潜伏在其他地方。这是一个令人担忧的前景，因为中国金融已经受到问题的困扰。地方政府正在努力偿还贷款人至少 65 万亿人民币（9 万亿美元）的表外债务。中国许多最大的房地产开发商已经出现境外债券违约，并欠当地居民价值数万亿人民币的未建房屋。中国最大的财富管理公司已开始拖欠投资者的款项。鉴于此类隐性债务迄今尚未引起人们的关注，锦州的麻烦应该值得警惕。

向最小的公司提供贷款的问题始于 covid-19 的爆发。随着2020年1月中国经济停摆，央行将小微企业贷款暂停偿还至当年6月，以遏制一波违约潮。该政策实施不到三个月，官方估计约7000亿元人民币的付款已被推迟。此后，由于新冠疫情的持续影响，该禁令已多次延长。目前还没有对未付贷款总额的估计，并且银行在明年之前不需要公开披露这些金额。

此次暂停还与另一项国家举措同时进行。为了刺激经济，中央政府依靠银行向最小的企业提供贷款，并以尽可能低的利率提供贷款。尽管此类政策已尝试多年，但银行一直持抵制态度，更愿意向已经与其建立关系的大型企业（通常是国有企业）提供贷款。不过，这一次政策发挥了作用。去年，对银行业的打压最终导致中国最大商业银行之一的行长被捕，这使得老板们更愿意遵守官方法令。

因此，今年年初，中国约 28% 的贷款发放给了小微企业，高于 2019 年底的 24%。其中许多贷款只是旧贷款的更新，未偿还的债务。众所周知，小企业在疫情期间举步维艰。尽管如此，Natixis 银行的 Alicia Garcia Herrero 指出，不良贷款几乎没有增加。

另一个结果是一些分析师认为是灾难性的资产定价错误。小企业通常被认为风险最大，但向小微企业提供的贷款利率却处于最低水平。银行提供的平均年利率为 4%，低于 2019 年的 6% 左右。更糟糕的是，近期长期存款激增（利率较高）意味着银行的利润率受到挤压甚至更紧。

只有少数贷款机构暗示了他们推迟的贷款金额。中国最大的银行之一民生银行在去年的中期报告中表示，在过去六个月中，该行已提供了人民币 2120 亿元的续贷和延期还款，相当于其企业贷款总额的 9% 左右。从那时起，它就拒绝做出类似的披露。央行正在向银行提供资金，可用于支持经济的特定部分。它在最近的一份报告中表示，今年上半年已向小企业发放了 2.7 万亿人民币的贷款。

任何暂停贷款都伴随着一场赌博：短期的宽恕和更新将使陷入困境的公司在经济冲击后重新站起来。最初的决定可能使数万家公司甚至几家银行免于破产。现在，这堆模糊债务的命运——无论数额有多大——取决于中国未来几个月的经济命运。尽管制造商采购经理指数显示，近几个月来大型企业的前景略有改善，但中小企业的采购经理指数却继续萎缩。新冠疫情时代的经济后遗症依然挥之不去。现在这种情况可能会加剧。 ■

一块布满灰尘、磨损的混凝土板是许多加沙人逃离噩梦的最后希望，这场噩梦将伴随着以色列即将到来的地面进攻。电力、粮食进口和供水被切断，在持续的轰炸下，已有 2000 多人丧生，近一半人口流离失所。在以色列警告清理北部地区后，加沙居民正在淹没通往南部的道路。然而，拉法门贯穿了加沙南部与埃及之间11公里长的隔离墙，也是唯一非以色列人出境的通道，自10月7日哈马斯对以色列发动残酷袭击以来一直关闭。

了解有关以色列和哈马斯之间战争的更多信息

据报道，美国正试图让自己的公民走出国门。该地区许多人希望，为了避免人道主义灾难，塞西先生可能会改变主意并允许难民逃离加沙。 10 月 15 日，安东尼·布林肯将抵达开罗，作为美国国务卿中东之行的最后一刻补充。对埃及陷入危机的经济的潜在救助能否为外国外交官提供影响力的手段？

埃及以前曾做过这样的交易。 1991年，海湾战争结束三个月后，美国和其他西方国家让埃及摆脱了100亿美元的借款，占当时外债的四分之一。这也是对地缘政治恩惠的回报。当其他阿拉伯国家集结军队并在沙特阿拉伯观望时，时任埃及总统胡斯尼·穆巴拉克是第一批派遣武装部队加入美国打击伊拉克的领导人之一。

埃及的经济再次崩溃。年通胀率为 38%，为历史最高水平；埃及镑正在暴跌，因为中央银行通过印钞来支付政府通过面包补贴和对国有企业的支持来支付过高的账单。国际货币基金组织去年 12 月同意提供 30 亿美元的救助资金，但由于缺乏偿还贷款的信心，拒绝移交最新两期援助资金。从注入现金来弥补开罗的预算赤字，到达成进口协议，其他国家不乏可以提供的优惠措施。

如果外国外交官想要取得成功，他们必须克服三个挑战。一是塞西先生可能还没有绝望。埃及经济可能陷入困境，但政府并没有像 1991 年那样面临直接违约的危险。在 2024 年之前，埃及几乎不需要支付大笔款项，其 300 亿美元的外汇储备足以支付四个月的进口。

另一个复杂之处是埃及目前几乎不欠美国任何东西。该国的大部分借款来自私人银行和本币债券，这意味着美国无法削减其债务。一些外交官希望布林肯能够加快从国际货币基金组织获得资金，甚至削减开罗欠该多边贷款机构 160 亿美元的部分资金。然而，该基金只提供适度的资助，限制了这种方法的吸引力。这给美国留下了一个选择：向埃及注入新的资金，但这会遭到华盛顿的反对。

第二个挑战涉及埃及欠债的国家。该国一半以上的外债以及几乎全部外汇储备都来自阿拉伯联合酋长国、卡塔尔和沙特阿拉伯。每个国家都向埃及中央银行提供了数十亿美元的存款；最近的一揽子计划包括去年 11 月来自沙特阿拉伯的 50 亿美元和来自卡塔尔的 30 亿美元。这种类型的贷款可以在短时间内撤回，而且这样的撤回数额足以耗尽埃及的美元。因此，与美国不同，海湾地区确实对开罗有影响力。因此，任何交易都需要该地区国家的参与。

最后，埃及需要得到保证，它不会独自应对加沙难民。让数十万需要教育、医疗保健和住房的人越过边境的担忧是他们会留下来。以色列何时让加沙人返回以及他们返回后会留下什么，存在巨大的不确定性。在约旦和黎巴嫩，难民已成为一个痛苦的政治问题，1940 年代从巴勒斯坦和 2010 年代从叙利亚带走了数十万人。布林肯和海湾国家需要让埃及官员相信，其他国家愿意为一些通过拉法门的人提供费用，甚至可能为他们提供住房。否则埃及经济将难以应对，这一点塞西先生非常清楚。 ■

; Sat, 14 Oct 2023 19:57:23 GMT /内容/8ej7pmcps6ifoocacbkg6l8eb7jleoor https://www.economist.com/finance-and-economics/2023/10/14/can-egypt-be-persuaded-to-accept-gazan-refugees To beat populists, sensible policymakers must up their game

政客们，庆幸吧。说到选举，明年是一个重要的一年。当然，到 2024 年，共和党和民主党将在美国一决胜负，但阿尔及利亚、印度、墨西哥、巴基斯坦、俄罗斯、南非、台湾，可能还有英国和许多其他国家也将进行这样或那样的投票除了。总而言之，在生产了全球GDP约三分之一的国家中，多达 30 亿人将有机会在方框中打上“X”。在其中许多地方，民粹主义政客的民调都表现良好。他们的成功对全球经济意味着什么？

经济学家长期以来一直怀疑民粹主义者会造成严重损害。智利的萨尔瓦多·阿连德和意大利的西尔维奥·贝卢斯科尼等名字很难等同于经济能力。相比之下，你所谓的“明智”领导人，比如德国的康拉德·阿登纳和美国的比尔·克林顿，往往与强劲增长联系在一起。 《美国经济评论》 （也许是该学科最负盛名的期刊）即将发表的新研究为这一预感提供了确凿的数据。

作者基尔世界经济研究所的 Manuel Funke 和 Christoph Trebesch 以及波恩大学的 Moritz Schularick 研究了一个多世纪的数据。他们根据政府的意识形态是否具有“我们与他们”的风格，将政府分为“民粹主义”或“非民粹主义”（或者你可能称之为明智的）。这不可避免地是一种任意的做法。人们对于这个或那个政府是否真的应该被归类为民粹主义政府存在分歧。然而他们的方法是透明的，并得到其他学术研究的支持。

芬克先生和同事随后研究了两种政体之间的各种结果（包括国内生产总值增长和通货膨胀）有何不同。诀窍在于找出反事实——民粹主义政府统治下的国家在更明智的政权下会如何表现。为此，作者创建了“分身”政府，使用一种算法来建立一个跟踪该国前民粹主义治理表现的经济体。例如，在贝卢斯科尼 2001 年至 2011 年担任总理期间的大部分时间里，作者将意大利的经济与主要由塞浦路斯、卢森堡和秘鲁组成的幻影意大利进行了比较。这三个国家与世界第八大经济体有共同特征，包括严重依赖国际贸易。

作者确定了 1900 年至 2020 年间的 51 位民粹主义总统和总理，得出了惊人的结果。在两到三年的时间里，在民粹主义和明智的领导下的国家之间的实际国内生产总值的发展轨迹几乎没有什么差别。有一段时间，似乎可以妖魔化你的对手并粗暴对待财产权，而不会产生太大的后果。然而，差距最终会出现，也许是因为外国投资者开始将目光投向其他地方。民粹主义政府上台 15 年后，作者发现人均GDP比合理的反事实情况低了 10%，令人痛苦。公共债务与国内生产总值的比率也较高，通货膨胀也是如此。作者坚信，民粹主义对钱包不利。

对于那些相信可敬的政治家做正确的事情的重要性的人来说，这一结果令人欣慰。但如果理智不再像以前那样怎么办？尽管芬克和他的同事无法判断最近民粹主义浪潮的记录，但一些例子表明，理性主义者和民粹主义者之间的差距可能没有以前那么大。在唐纳德·特朗普总统的领导下，美国经济基本超出了预期。雷杰普·塔伊普·埃尔多安压制了土耳其的言论自由，但相对于同类国家，实际经济增长相当强劲。在纳伦德拉·莫迪的领导下，印度经济蓬勃发展：今年其国内生产总值可能增长 6% 左右，而全球增长率约为 3%。在民粹主义领导下，匈牙利和波兰的表现并不明显比其他国家差。

鉴于特朗普的关税和埃尔多安不同寻常的货币政策，这些国家的相对成功不太可能归因于明智的政策制定。相反，它们相对强劲的表现可能反映出这样一个事实：具有明智领导力的国家发现实现增长更加困难。 20 世纪 60 年代，西方国家正从第二次世界大战中重建，人口年轻，年增长率有望达到 5% 或更高。因此，经济管理不善的机会成本很高。如今，部分由于人口老龄化，潜在增长率较低。因此，有能力的政府和无能力的政府之间的国内生产总值增长差距可能会更小。

然而，明智的政客们也正在犯错。过去，他们向选民承诺更高的收入，然后说明如何实现这些收入，然后实施必要的政策。根据专栏作家对研究项目“宣言项目”的数据分析，如今，由大多数富裕国家组成的经合组织俱乐部的政治家承诺的促增长政策数量是 20 世纪 90 年代的一半。他们实施的改革也较少：到 2010 年代，产品和劳动力市场改革实际上已经停止。与此同时，政客们对住房建设设置了巨大障碍，导致成本上升并限制了生产率的增长。许多人将注意力集中在通过慷慨的养老金和医疗保健资金来取悦老年选民上。

灰色的影子

民粹主义者本身不太可能解决这些问题。但明智的做法是提供什么替代方案呢？技术官僚、温和的政府需要重新获得增长优势。毕竟，认为特立独行的政客会损害经济的信念是阻碍更多人投票支持他们的主要因素之一。如果人们对明智政府的经济能力的怀疑加深，那么投票给头脑风暴者的风险似乎就不那么大了。尽管纵观历史，经济学家嘲笑民粹主义者的经济政策是正确的，但今天，明智的人也需要整顿自己的事情。 ■

; Thu, 12 Oct 2023 09:47:54 GMT /内容/dg634ses1riiph5dti8vijbqqa6c13on https://www.economist.com/finance-and-economics/2023/10/12/to-beat-populists-sensible-policymakers-must-up-their-game Investors should treat analysis of bond yields with caution

美国政治战略家詹姆斯·卡维尔经常重复地说，如果他有转世，他希望以债券市场的身份回归，因为它有能力恐吓所有人。你的专栏作家会更具体：他会以收益率曲线的形式回来。如果说债券市场是一股可怕的力量，那么收益率曲线就是恐怖力量的顶点。无论它转向哪个方向，似乎都会引起干扰。

去年10月，当收益率曲线倒挂时，长期债券收益率低于短期债券收益率，分析师们对所发出的信号感到痛苦。毕竟，曲线倒挂往往伴随着经济衰退。但现在曲线似乎正在迅速反转。衡量十年期和两年期债券收益率差异的、受到广泛关注的 10-2 利差已显着收窄。 7 月份，两年期国债收益率比十年期国债收益率高出 1.1 个百分点，这是 40 年来的最大差距。此后，它们的差距更加接近，两次收益率之间仅相差 0.3 个百分点。

由于收益率曲线倒挂被视为一个可怕的预兆，因此投资者认为收益率曲线倒挂是一个积极信号也是情有可原的。事实上，在“熊市陡峭期”，即长期债券比短期债券抛售幅度更大的时期（与“牛市陡峭期”相反，在“牛市陡峭期”，短期债券比长期债券上涨幅度更大），被认为是市场动物学中另一个厄运的预兆。

引发最新恐慌的是不断上升的期限溢价，考虑到如此长期限内的额外不确定性，期限溢价通常被描述为投资者持有较长期证券所需的额外收益。据美联储纽约分行估计，十年期债券溢价较今年最低水平上升了1.2个百分点，这足以解释近期长期债券收益率的飙升。

但事实上，溢价一词是一个模糊的概念，必须谨慎对待。它不能直接测量。相反，与数量惊人的重要经济现象一样，分析师必须通过衡量金融体系中更具体的部分并查看剩下的部分来梳理出问题。估计十年期债券的溢价需要预测未来十年的预测短期利率，并查看它们与十年期收益率的差异有多大。剩下的——无论大小——就是期限溢价。

困难还不止于此。斯坦福大学胡佛研究所的约翰·科克伦指出，尽管在相对较短的期限内风险溢价可能更容易估计，但随着分析师沿着曲线移动，计算需要对短期利率的未来做出越来越多的假设。当期限溢价的估计值发布时，通常不会附带误差幅度。如果是的话，预测进行的时间越长，利润率就会逐渐扩大。

令人惊讶的是，在评估收益率曲线或期限溢价的变化时，可以借鉴的历史也很少。在过去的40年里，大约有八次有意义的熊市陡峭期，而只有其中三年收益率曲线已经倒挂。 1990 年、2000 年和 2008 年这三次经济衰退之后都出现了经济衰退，但滞后时间差异很大。

因此，债券市场的变动既容易解释又难以解释。它们很容易解释，因为许多因素都可能推动收益率，包括美联储的量化紧缩计划、对美国债务可持续性的担忧以及对机构衰退的担忧。然而，将债券收益率归因于某一特定因素却充满困难。如果不能更清楚地了解波动的原因，从收益率曲线的形状推断未来就变得更像是在读茶叶，而不是科学的努力。

然而，有一件事是确定的。无论其原因是什么，也无论其构成如何，长期债券收益率的上升对于希望长期借款的美国公司以及申请与 30 年期利率挂钩的新抵押贷款的借款人来说都是可怕的消息。如果长期收益率保持在如此高的水平，对最敏感的借款人的影响只会变得更加痛苦。对于那些担心收益率曲线变化或期限溢价上升是否预示着即将到来的衰退或市场噩梦的人来说，这些简单的现实是一个更好的起点。 ■

; Thu, 12 Oct 2023 09:45:58 GMT /内容/g3m5hkm37f25hb1hnqo9asaqjiour1t5 https://www.economist.com/finance-and-economics/2023/10/12/investors-should-treat-analysis-of-bond-yields-with-caution Retail investors have a surprising new favourite: Treasury bills

当国债（或国库券）的收益率上次达到今天的水平（5.5%）时，投资者们松了口气，因为世界没有被千年虫摧毁，天命真女名列榜首，互联网泡沫正在强劲发展。 。最近收益率的飙升非常引人注目（见图表）。

然而，银行储户只看到了这些增长的一小部分。美国储蓄账户的平均收益率仅为 0.45%。投资者也错失良机。去年年底，六个月期国债的回报率首次超过了标准普尔500 指数公司的盈利收益率，这是二十多年来的首次。

因此散户投资者正在寻找其他地方。交易平台已将短期国债产品作为其产品的重要组成部分。 Public 是此类平台之一，其广告询问播客听众是否意识到自己的存款账户储蓄率微薄。尽管自 3 月份以来，国债才在该平台上提供，但目前国债已成为其购买量最大的资产。十分之一的新用户将其作为第一笔交易购买。

对国债的需求反映出人们更广泛地转向安全、高收益的选择。货币市场基金投资于低风险、短期工具，包括国债。今年此类基金的增资额已超过 8800 亿美元，使其总价值达到 5.7 万亿美元的历史新高。与零售短期国债账户一样，货币市场基金对储户很有吸引力，因为它们具有高流动性，这意味着如果需要，可以快速提取现金。

此类替代方案的日益普及正在扰乱零售银行业务的逻辑。银行提供的利率远低于短期政府债务的利息，而侥幸逃脱惩罚，因为正如公众广告所指出的那样，许多储户很少关注。通过吸收银行系统的存款，货币市场基金被认为是导致春季金融不稳定的原因之一。

零售交易平台的扩张使储户比以往任何时候都更容易将资金转入短期政府债务。这可能会进一步削弱储户从银行接受的储蓄利率折扣，并使国债成为零售投资组合中更大的组成部分。然后，储户将跟着命运之子最好的曲调之一唱歌：“账单，账单，账单”。 ■

; Thu, 12 Oct 2023 09:42:21 GMT /内容/t6tmi38is650765uor4ugd868qevt8kr https://www.economist.com/finance-and-economics/2023/10/12/retail-investors-have-a-surprising-new-favourite-treasury-bills Corporate America faces a trillion-dollar debt reckoning

美国大公司正生活在债务梦境中。尽管几十年来廉价借贷推动了企业利润的增长，但最大的企业基本上没有受到美联储最近一轮货币紧缩政策的影响。这是因为在 covid-19 大流行期间，他们中的许多人以低固定利率大量借贷。最终必须通过以高得多的利率对债务进行再融资来解决这一问题。不过，就目前而言，所谓的到期债务期限墙看起来是可扩展的。

但并非所有公司都摆脱了美联储行动的影响。事实上，有数万亿美元的浮动利率债务，其利息支付随着市场的变化而突然变得更加昂贵。这堆债务包括杠杆贷款和来自私人债务市场的借款。公司很少对冲利率风险，这意味着他们现在发现自己付出了高昂的代价——一项杠杆贷款指数的到期收益率已跃升至近 10%（见图 1）。与此同时，由于美国经济增长依然强劲，美联储政策制定者警告称，利率将不得不在更长时间内保持较高水平。这将把更多的借款人推向崩溃点。一个日益庞大的市场现在面临着两个令人痛苦的问题。事情会变得多么糟糕？到底谁会失败呢？

自2007-09年全球金融危机以来，企业借贷快速而宽松。瑞银银行估计美国未偿杠杆贷款的价值约为 1.4 万亿美元，而私人信贷机构管理的资产则超过 1.5 万亿美元。这两种类型的债务相似之处多于不同之处。两者的发展都是为了服务过去十年的私募股权收购热潮。传统的杠杆贷款由银行安排，然后出售（或“银团”）给数十名投资者，而民间借贷只涉及少数基金，这些基金通常持有较小的到期贷款，从而形成流动性较低且更加不透明的市场。

现在，越来越多的借款人陷入困境。自2010年以来，杠杆贷款市场的年平均违约率一直低于2%。惠誉 (Fitch) 的数据显示，截至 7 月份的 12 个月内，违约率从去年同期的 1% 上升至 3%。该评级机构估计，到 2024 年，这一数字可能会飙升至 4.5%。这种规模的重组和破产相当于春季大扫除，而不是金融危机期间贷款违约率超过 10% 的深度困境。但如果正如央行行长预测的那样，利率在较长时间内保持较高水平，陷入困境的公司数量将会增加。尽管所有拥有未对冲浮动利率债务余额的公司都很脆弱，但那些在近期交易热潮期间以高估值私募股权收购而背负债务的公司尤其面临风险。

利润增长放缓意味着借款人发现更难负担浮动利率债务。摩根大通银行在 6 月底、即美联储最近一次加息之前对 285 家杠杆贷款借款人进行了分析。借款仅由杠杆贷款组成的企业的年利息支出同比飙升51%。他们的命运与那些利用高收益债券市场购买固定利率基金的人截然不同。研究显示，此类业务的利息支出增幅不到3%。将公司利润与其利息成本进行比较的覆盖率已经开始出现不祥的下降（见图2）。

在违约率往往较高的私人债务市场，借款人也面临着类似的困境。据美国银行称，对于那些由最大的商业开发公司（一种投资工具）持有贷款的公司来说，利息成本现在消耗了一半的利润。困境的大幅上升不仅会导致更难找到愿意将资金投入私人债务基金的机构（投资者通常会被平稳回报的承诺所吸引），而且还会蔓延到杠杆贷款市场。

现在清算似乎迫在眉睫，人们的注意力开始转向哪些投资者将承担责任。如今，贷款人预计在公司违约后收回的投资比以前要少，而且今年垃圾级债务的所谓回收率已远低于其长期平均水平。另一家银行高盛的洛特菲·卡鲁伊表示，完全依赖贷款而不是从债券市场借款的借款人的增加可能会进一步抑制经济复苏。这一趋势集中了利率上升带来的痛苦。当杠杆贷款投资者面临重组或进入破产法庭时，他们的价值也可能会减少，因为会有更多针对公司资产的债权。

其他长期趋势可能会加剧杠杆贷款市场的问题。随着市场的成熟，维护契约、贷方可以用作强制重组的“大棒”的承诺几乎消失了。 2021 年，近 90% 的新增贷款属于“低门槛”贷款。这可能意味着企业需要更长的时间才能达到违约状态，而且到达违约状态时的健康状况会更差。过度的“加回”以及对公司盈利能力指标的奉承调整也可能意味着杠杆借款人的状况比市场认为的更糟糕。

私人市场的表现也受到密切关注。私人债务的倡导者长期以来一直认为，私人债务更适合违约率较高的时期，因为一小群贷款人之间的协调成本较低，从而更容易纠正令人烦恼的资产负债表。如果在即将到来的动荡期间，私人市场确实比杠杆贷款表现更好，那么这将有利于他们未来吸引融资的努力。

浮动利率债务市场的问题不太可能引发金融危机，但私人市场的黑暗和规模不断扩大尤其意味着监管机构已决定进行更仔细的调查。八月，美国证券交易委员会宣布了提高透明度的规则，包括要求季度财务报表。接下来的一个月，全球监管机构国际证券委员会组织就杠杆风险和私人债务市场的不透明性发出了警告。然而，很少有投资者认为他们需要帮助来预测即将到来的紧缩。 ■

; Thu, 12 Oct 2023 09:40:29 GMT /内容/f722qrqku5juqo93o5ci6018o6qtpnos https://www.economist.com/finance-and-economics/2023/10/12/corporate-america-faces-a-trillion-dollar-debt-reckoning How economists have underestimated Chinese consumption

亚当·斯密指出：“消费是所有生产的唯一目的和目的。”但他的“完全不言而喻”的格言在中国从未产生过太大影响。今年早些时候，中国统计人员透露，2022年家庭消费占中国GDP的比重仅为37%，为2014年以来的最低水平。

尽管取消covid-19 控制措施应该有助于提高这一数字，但对中国数据的调整可能会提高更多。中国的总体统计数据可能低估了家庭收入和消费。仔细观察，两者似乎都比报道的要高，而且都上升得更快。

近二十年来，中国决策者一直寻求“重新平衡”经济，从出口和投资转向更直接的满足感支出。例如，财政部在今年的预算中宣称，“我们将努力恢复和扩大消费……并通过多种渠道增加个人收入”。但进展缓慢。近年来，国际货币基金组织用不同颜色的“再平衡记分卡”对中国的努力进行了评级。最新的卡片是二月份发布的，大部分是红色的。

再平衡的倡导者通常会发现两个问题。首先，中国家庭将大量收入储蓄起来；其次，他们的收入在国家蛋糕中所占的份额太小。第二个问题在北京大学颇具影响力的教授迈克尔·佩蒂斯的论点中尤为突出。他指出，在西方，家庭收入通常占GDP的 70-80%。相比之下，中国的这一比例仅为 55%。他认为，再平衡必然涉及将财富和权力转移给普通民众。

事实上，一些观察家现在怀疑中国领导人习近平是否已经完全放弃了这一目标。对他来说，中国生产的目的不仅限于消费，还包括让中国成为一个有弹性的强国、减少对西方主导的“窒息”技术的依赖等野心。根据一位在 20 世纪 70 年代和 80 年代认识他的教授的泄露说法，年轻时的他“对中国社会全方位的商业化感到厌恶”。

不过，尽管习近平并不是再平衡的热心拥护者，但他的记分卡可能比普遍认为的要好。长期以来，经济学家一直认为中国的数据低估了家庭收入和支出。调查可能无法捕捉到富人未报告的“灰色”收入。而且国民账户可能仍然低估了房主居住在自己拥有的房产中时为自己支付的隐含“租金”。

鲜为人知的是，中国统计人员在计算政府以很少成本或无成本向个人提供的商品和服务时所付出的努力。这些转移包括教育和医疗保健，尤其是药品报销。它们还包括文化设施和补贴食品。弗吉尼亚大学的朱洪深重点介绍了社区食堂，这些食堂通常位于国有建筑内，但由私人承包商经营，以大幅折扣的价格提供平菇或辣黄瓜等美味佳肴。

根据国际标准，这些好东西应该作为“实物社会转移”（有时缩写为stik ）出现在官方统计数据中。然后可以将它们添加到家庭收入和消费中，以提供更全面的“调整后”情况。 “原则上，社会转移支付应包含在收入的完整定义中，”堪培拉小组 (Canberra Group) 的国际专家小组在 2001 年表示，尽管他们承认这在实践中并不容易做到。

中国尤其陷入困境。过去，它没有干净或单独地报告它们，而是将它们塞入国民账户的其他部分，包括政府消费。如果忽略这些转移支付，那么2020年中国家庭可支配收入仅为国民收入的62%（2010年低至56%）。正如佩蒂斯先生所说，这个数字似乎低得惊人。但这部分是因为它遗漏了一切。如果其他国家的可支配收入也扣除实物社会转移，那么它们的数字看起来更像中国。到 2020 年，欧元区的这一数字将低于 64%（见图 1）。按照这一标准，十几个欧洲国家的收入份额低于中国。

幸运的是，中国的统计人员现在可以做得更好。朱先生指出，过去几年，他们开始在年度统计年鉴中公布实物社会转移支付的数据。 2020 年，这些金额达到 6.8 万亿人民币（1 万亿美元，几乎占国民收入的 7%），占GDP的比重高于美国。这使得中国国家统计局能够发布“调整后”的可支配收入数据，从而更容易与经合组织国家进行国际比较。

加上这些实物社会转移支付，中国家庭收入占国民收入的比例升至69%，接近垫底，但并非最垫底。此外，由于过去十年它们的增长速度快于经济增长，它们使习近平的再平衡记录更加有希望。 Household consumption, including these transfers, increased from 39% of gdp in 2010 to 45% in 2019 before the pandemic struck (see chart 2).

Such revisions do make government consumption look weaker. And China's social transfers in kind, as a share of national income, are still not high compared with the oecd average. There is thus scope to raise them. If Mr Xi objects to the commercialisation of Chinese society, the state could instead provide more of the things that he thinks his citizens should be consuming. That would be a way for Mr Xi to rebalance towards consumption without reconciling himself to consumerism. ■

; Tue, 10 Oct 2023 16:01:24 GMT /content/qgh20pqrb7cml078boqsfded77ah9g1j https://www.economist.com/finance-and-economics/2023/10/10/how-economists-have-underestimated-chinese-consumption Claudia Goldin wins the Nobel prize in economics

O n the morning of October 9th the National Bureau of Economic Research circulated a working paper to economists around the world entitled “Why Women Won”. In the paper, Claudia Goldin of Harvard University documents how women achieved equal rights in American workplaces and families. Rather fittingly, a few hours later, Ms Goldin was announced as the winner of this year's economics Nobel prize, for advancing “our understanding of women's labour-market outcomes”.

Having been the first woman to be granted tenure at Harvard's economics department, Ms Goldin is now the third woman to have won the subject's Nobel prize. Taken together, her research provides a comprehensive history of gender labour-market inequality over the past 200 years. In telling this history , she has overturned assumptions about both historical gender relations and what is required to achieve greater equality in the present day.

Before Ms Goldin's work, economists had thought that economic growth led to a more level playing field. In fact, Ms Goldin showed, the Industrial Revolution drove married women out of the labour force, as production moved from home to factory. In research published in 1990 she demonstrated that it was only in the 20th century, when service-sector jobs proliferated and high-school education developed, that the more familiar pattern emerged. The relationship between the size of Western economies and female-labour-force participation is u -shaped—a classic Goldin result.

Ms Goldin's research has busted other myths, too. Lawrence Katz, her colleague and husband, marvels at her ability to trawl archives to fill gaps in the historical data on women's work. Simple statistics, such as the female employment rate, were mismeasured because when surveyed, women might respond “I'm a housewife”, notes Ms Goldin, even if they managed the family business. Once corrected, the employment rate for white married women, for example, was 12.5% in 1890—five times greater than previously thought.

Her findings also showed that the gender wage gap narrowed in bursts. Women's wages rose relative to men's in 1820-50 and then again in 1890-1930, before shooting up in 1980-2005 (see chart). What drove these bursts? The initial two came well before the equal-pay movement and were caused by changes in the labour market: first, during the Industrial Revolution; second, during a surge in white-collar employment for occupations like clerical work.

For the third and most substantial drop, in the late 20th century, Ms Goldin emphasises the role of expectations. If a young woman has more say over when and whether she will have a child, and more confidence that women can work in a wide range of jobs, she may invest more in the future, such as by staying in school for longer. In work published in 2002 Ms Goldin and Mr Katz detailed the example of the contraceptive pill, which was approved in 1960, and gave women more control over decisions about children. Between 1967 and 1979 the share of 20- and 21-year-old women who expected to be employed at 35 jumped from 35% to 80%.

Expectations also matter for employers. Although the pay gap narrowed in the early 1900s, the portion driven by discrimination, rather than job type, grew. An important factor, says Ms Goldin, was changes in how payment was decided. Wages used to be tied to output—how many clothes were knitted, for instance. But after industrialisation, workers were increasingly paid periodically, in part because measuring an individual's output became trickier. Therefore more ambiguous factors grew in importance, such as ideas about how long a worker would stay on the job. This penalised women, who were expected to quit when they had children.

Since around 2005 the wage gap has hardly budged. Here Ms Goldin's work questions popular narratives that continue to blame wage discrimination. Instead, in a book published in 2021, Ms Goldin blames “greedy” jobs, such as being a consultant or lawyer, which offer increasing returns to long (and uncertain) hours.

She explains how such work interacts with the so-called parenthood penalty. “Let's say there are two lawyers, equally brilliant,” explains Ms Goldin. Once children arrive, “they realise that they both can't work these gruelling hours.” Women spend more time raising children, which is why the gender pay gap tends to open up after a first child. Both partners could take on less demanding jobs, but then the couple would earn less as a unit, she explains.

Ms Goldin's research holds lessons for economists and policymakers. For the former group, it shows the importance of history. Ms Goldin's prize is the first economics Nobel awarded for work largely in economic history since Robert Fogel, her former adviser, triumphed in 1993. Before Ms Goldin's research, many academics considered questions about historical gender pay gaps to be unanswerable because of a paucity of data. Yet she has repeatedly demonstrated that digging through historical archives allows researchers to credibly answer big questions previously thought beyond their reach.

For policymakers, Ms Goldin's research demonstrates that fixes for gender inequality vary depending on time and place. In early 20th-century America, companies barred married women from obtaining or retaining employment. A policy response came with the Civil Rights Act of 1964, which banned such behaviour. Today, wage gaps persist because of greedy jobs and parental norms, rather than because of straightforward employer discrimination. In the past, Ms Goldin has suggested more flexibility in the workplace could be a solution to the problem. Perhaps working out how to achieve it will be her next act. ■

; Mon, 09 Oct 2023 20:45:24 GMT /content/eqq2kp6frh6ad6sb8pdtr8m8l0i14de7 https://www.economist.com/finance-and-economics/2023/10/09/claudia-goldin-wins-the-nobel-prize-in-economics A jobs bonanza stirs fears the American economy is overheating

T he american economy is supposed to be slowing down by now , and that is supposed to be translating into a weaker labour market. But according to figures released on October 6th, the country added 336,000 jobs in September, nearly twice as many as forecast and the most since January (see chart). It is the latest evidence that, despite an aggressive series of interest-rate increases by the Federal Reserve over the past 18 months, American growth remains resilient. Instead of the “hard-landing” forecasts that predicted a recession, and were so common earlier this year, America looks to be heading for something more like a “no-landing” scenario.

Underlying the data release is a vexing question, about whether the labour-market resilience is excessive, and will therefore place upward pressure on inflation. If so, Fed policymakers will be tempted to resume their interest-rate rises before long. In recent weeks financial markets have moved sharply to price in the possibility that rates will remain elevated for an extended period—or, to use the terminology now favoured, stay “higher for longer”—owing to the Fed's protracted fight against inflation. Yields on long-term Treasury bonds have soared since August to around 4.8%, their highest in more than 15 years, which represents a swift tightening of financial conditions.

Initial reactions to the strong jobs data fell into the good-news-is-bad-news mould. In the minutes after the release, yields on Treasuries jumped yet higher, reflecting bets that the Fed may raise rates again as soon as its next meeting, scheduled for the end of this month. That, in turn, weighed on stockmarkets globally.

However, as analysts and investors digested the numbers, worries about the outlook for rates gave way to optimism about the broader economy, because the employment report also offered pretty positive signals about inflation. Average hourly earnings—a proxy for wage growth—were up 0.2% month-on-month in September, the slowest monthly rise since early 2022. In year-on-year terms, earnings growth of 4.2% dipped to its weakest since mid-2021. Alongside a recent deceleration in inflation, an ebbing of wage pressures will reassure the Fed that prices are trending in the desired direction.

A separate batch of labour-market data published at the same time—based on a survey of households rather than businesses—also painted a more restrained picture. It showed that just 86,000 jobs were added last month. With 90,000 people entering the workforce at the same time, the unemployment rate remained perfectly steady at 3.8%, which is low by historical standards but a touch higher than a few months ago. All this suggests that the labour market has gone from being ultra-tight to just moderately tight . Viewed in such a light, America's economic resilience would appear to be impressive, not excessive. ■

; Fri, 06 Oct 2023 18:01:09 GMT /content/jgknivql8a46omqifea20eeje1hc22gn https://www.economist.com/finance-and-economics/2023/10/06/a-jobs-bonanza-stirs-fears-the-american-economy-is-overheating To understand America’s job market, look beyond unemployed workers

S itting in a medical clinic recently, as a young-looking nurse extracted blood from his veins, your columnist's mind turned to the flexibility of the American labour market. How long, exactly, had she been on the job? The somewhat shocking answer: it was her first month. Six weeks of training was all it took, she explained, to make the transition from eyelash technician to phlebotomist, which offered higher pay and better hours.

Workers ditching old jobs for better ones has been a feature of the post-covid American economy. Early last year about 3% of Americans quit their jobs in any given month, the highest in two decades. Since July that has fallen to 2.3%, back to its pre-pandemic level. The decline is a sign that the labour market is gradually normalising. It has gone from being ultra-tight—beset by a seemingly endless worker shortage—to merely moderately tight.

During the period of ultra-tightness, analysts and investors paid close attention to a chart. The Beveridge curve, named after William Beveridge, a mid-20th-century British economist, depicts the link between unemployment and job vacancies. It is an inverse relationship: vacancies rise as unemployment falls. The logic is simple. When nearly all would-be workers have jobs, companies struggle to find new staff and have more vacancies.

What makes the Beveridge curve fascinating but also frustrating is that it moves around. There is no fixed relationship between vacancies and unemployment. Take, for instance, an unemployment rate of 6%. This was consistent with about 2.5% of jobs in America being unfilled in the early 2000s, but 3.5% in the 2010s and 6% in 2021. As a rule, the higher the vacancy level for any given unemployment rate, the less efficient the labour market, since firms must fight to find workers. In graphical terms, an inefficient Beveridge curve shifts outwards, away from the origin point.

The fascinating bit is the explanation for this. Normally, the location of the Beveridge curve is viewed as a measure of skills-matching. If workers lack the skills wanted by employers, the vacancy rate will be higher. During covid-19 and its aftermath, though, the problem was less a skills mismatch than a willingness mismatch. Many people were scared of illness and thus less willing to work. At the same time, having profited from a rapid recovery, many companies were willing to hire additional workers.

An exceedingly inefficient labour market was the result. There were two job openings per unemployed person at the start of 2022, the most on record. Given such a Beveridge curve, the dismal conclusion was that unemployment would soar as the Federal Reserve wrestled down inflation. The causal chain went like this: to tame inflation, the Fed had to generate slower wage growth; for wages to slow, vacancies had to fall; finally, in an inefficient labour market, a big fall in vacancies implied a big rise in unemployment.

Skip ahead to the present, though, and these fears have receded. Job vacancies have declined without much unemployment. There are now 1.5 job openings per unemployed worker. The labour market, in other words, looks more efficient. The Beveridge curve has shifted inwards, reverting to somewhere close to its pre-pandemic location. The typical explanation is that the willingness mismatch has abated: Americans have re-entered the labour force, while companies have cut their help-wanted advertisements.

Question everything

That, at least, is the conventional story. But think about it for a second and it is does not sit quite right. After all, the Beveridge curve is supposed to depict the state of the labour market. If, however, the curve itself is liable to move around, as this story suggests, it surely cannot be of much use. Do adjustments take place along the curve or does the curve itself change locations? After the fact it seems clear enough. In the moment, it is guesswork.

There is a different, and better, way of constructing the Beveridge curve. The standard curve implies that it is the unemployed who fill job vacancies.正如专栏作家的抽血医生所证明的那样，问题在于，实际上，填补空缺的往往是跳槽者，而不是失业者。 In research published by the Fed's branch in St Louis, Anton Cheremukhin, Praew Grittayaphong and Paulina Restrepo-Echavarría have reflected this, proposing a revised Beveridge curve that links prospective job-switchers to vacancies.

Instead of the inverse traditional curve, their one has a positive slope: as vacancies rise, more workers consider jumping ship for new jobs. Indeed, they find that about four-fifths of vacancies since 2015 have been geared towards job-switchers, not the jobless. Along with its faithfulness to reality, their curve has another advantage in that it appears to be mostly stable. The pandemic was unusual because of the large rise in both job vacancies and job seekers, but that was an extrapolation of their revised curve, not a shift to a new location. One conclusion is that a relatively soft landing looks more plausible today. Although a decline in vacancies is still needed to calm wage growth, that largely translates into less job-switching rather than higher unemployment.

There may be a more profound lesson to draw. In 2020 Katharine Abraham and colleagues at the University of Maryland also looked at whether they could improve the Beveridge curve, this time by incorporating job searchers who are already employed or out of the labour force. Their revised curve, like that of the St Louis Fed's economists, is more stable than the traditional curve. The implication of that stability is that the economy actually does a decent job of matching workers with jobs.

Many people, including politicians from both sides of the aisle, declare that America is plagued by a skills mismatch. Yet the evidence suggests that workers respond to wages, and that firms which are willing to invest can train them up. The skills shortage may be more of a talking-point than a fundamental constraint to growth. Remember: America is a country in which eyelash technicians can become phlebotomists in a matter of weeks. ■

; Thu, 05 Oct 2023 10:28:07 GMT /content/i10a69b3dibgt211g7vj1513gdor4q4g https://www.economist.com/finance-and-economics/2023/10/05/to-understand-americas-job-market-look-beyond-unemployed-workers China’s greying population is refusing to save for retirement

H ongbaos are usually reserved for special occasions, such as birthdays, weddings and the Chinese mid-autumn festival, which got under way on September 29th. But now these red envelopes, stuffed with cash, are part of a push by China's banks to get citizens thinking about retirement. They are being offered to customers who register for private-pension accounts.

Under a law introduced last November, workers may set aside savings in tax-deferred accounts accessible upon retirement, much like America's Individual Retirement Accounts ( ira s). Those who want to enrol must open an account with a bank, before allocating their deposits to a licensed wealth manager. Savers can deduct contributions from taxable income; they pay no tax on capital gains and only a 3% tax rate at the time of distribution.

If these terms sound attractive, it is because officials cannot afford for the scheme to fail. Chinese workers retire young—as early as 50 for women and 60 for men. Last year the population shrank for the first time since Mao Zedong's “Great Leap Forward” in 1962, even as the number of old folk grew. China's compulsory basic pension, which has more than a billion enrollees and is paid for through employer contributions, will be in deficit by 2028 and run out entirely by 2035, according to modelling by an official think-tank.

When the reforms were introduced, analysts estimated that they would raise the value of China's private pensions from $300bn (which had accumulated during the pilot version of the scheme), to at least $1.7trn by 2025. Such a pot would rival the world's largest pension funds and give officials capital to channel to favoured industries. The scheme would also give Chinese people a new avenue for saving, drawing them away from the country's troubled property market. Unfortunately, though, things are not going entirely to plan.

Banks, which are mostly state-owned, have offered customers incentives to open accounts, including discounts on phone bills, rewards for referrals and even free ibuprofen (there was a shortage at the time). Although these have lured customers, with more than 40m having signed up by June, getting them to actually save is a struggle. In March fewer than one-third of accounts contained funds. The government has since stopped releasing figures, but there is little reason to believe that savings have risen in the intervening period. Moreover, the president of one bank estimates that 70% of funds deposited go uninvested, remaining in bank accounts, perhaps because depositors want to enjoy the tax advantages without entering financial markets they perceive to be risky.

What is going wrong? Some of the problems facing the pension system reflect its design. Banks, with which customers are required to open accounts, are unfazed by the low contributions. They simply want to beat their rivals on sign-ups, and some are too busy defusing bad debts to focus on pensions, notes an analyst.

But there are deeper issues at play, too. Officials say that workers are unaware of the importance of pension planning. Bankers propose bigger tax breaks and a higher maximum contribution, which is currently 12,000 yuan ($1,700) a year, or 15% of the average disposable income in Shanghai. Neither group wants to confront the possibility that the problem is even more profound. Chinese stockmarkets have long struggled to attract investors, with households preferring property. Financial assets are seen as too volatile—and too vulnerable to political interference.

The situation is unlikely to improve any time soon. Pension pots cannot be invested offshore, meaning that they do not offer a way to escape a weak domestic economy. Local stockmarkets are not exactly becoming any more alluring: Shanghai's main equity index is down this year. The government is also expected to raise the retirement age, which delays when savers can gain access to their investments. Last month the pensions ministry was forced to refuse requests from working-age depositors to withdraw their funds. All this means that another worry—a failing private pension system—can be added to the long list facing Chinese policymakers. ■
